definition: skilled manipulator/tactician/strategist/advisor/counsellor
to plan/to seek/scheme
member of the senior ministerial class (old)/scholar (old)/bachelor/honorific/soldier/noncommissioned officer/specialist worker
surname Shi

sentences.english: With kings and counsellors of the earth, which build desolate places for themselves;
sentences.chinese: 和地上爲自己重造荒邱的君王，謀士。

sentences.english: He leadeth counsellors away spoiled, and maketh the judges fools.
sentences.chinese: 他把謀士剝衣擄去，又使審判官變成愚人。

sentences.english: In fact, besides the apparent cause of the opportune, the talents, especially the advisors had a pivotal role in the Three Kingdoms.
sentences.chinese: 謀士集團在三國鼎立中有着舉足輕重的作用。
亞希多弗也作王的謀士。

sentences.english: Because war is managed by due ordering: and there shall be safety where there are many counsels.
sentences.chinese: 因爲作戰須有智謀，勝利在於謀士衆多。

sentences.english: He leadeth counsellors away spoiled, and makes the judges fools.
sentences.chinese: 他把謀士剝衣擄去，又使審判官變成愚人。

sentences.english: In the multitude of counsellors there is safety.
Duke Chao admired him so much that he game him a job as an advisor.
sentences.chinese: 魯昭公很讚賞他，讓他擔當謀士。

sentences.english: Then lots were cast for his son Zechariah, a wise counselor, and the lot for the North Gate fell to him.
sentences.chinese: 他的兒子撒迦利亞是精明的謀士，掣籤守北門。

definition: Lü Buwei (?291-235 BC), merchant and politician of the State of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], subsequent Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin2 dai4] Chancellor, allegedly the father of Ying Zheng 嬴政[Ying2 Zheng4], who subsequently became the first emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2]
Sima Yan (236-290), founding emperor of Jin dynasty 晋 after the Three Kingdoms period, reigned 265-290 as Emperor Wu of Jin 晉武帝
talented field commander (military)
Emperor Xian of Han (181-234), the final Han emperor, set up by Dong Zhuo 董卓, reigned 189-220, forced to abdicate 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕
Liu Biao (142-208), warlord
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
imperial strategic adviser/expert on strategy
to kill/to murder
Emperor Wen of Han (202-157 BC), fourth Han emperor, personal name Liu Heng 劉恆|刘恒[Liu2 Heng2], reigned 180-157 BC
scoundrel/rogue/bully/villain
Fu Jian (338-385), emperor of Former Qin 前秦[Qian2 Qin2], reigning from 357-385
Sima Zhao (211-265), military general and statesman of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4]
general/military leader/fierce man
Pang Juan (-342 BC), military leader and political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (425-221 BC)
military leadership/military power
Sun Ce (175-200), general and major warlord of the Later Han Dynasty
